newsitem.title: GERMANY: US farm land expansion seen limited -Toepfer.
newsitem.headline: US farm land expansion seen limited -Toepfer.

text.p: Expansions in U.S. arable areas are limited although Conservation Reserve Programme (CRP) contracts are set to expire next year, German grain trader Toepfer's latest newsletter said.
It was unlikely that more than 10 million acres would be converted back into arable land.
Toepfer said that currently some 33.6 million acres were sitting idle under CRP contracts.
The programme was created in 1985 to pay farmers an annual rent to take environmentally fragile land out of production for 10 years.
Most contracts will expire in 1997 and eligibility for a return into production, permanent idling, or renewed CRP contracts will depend on erodibility criteria.
Toepfer said possible effects would be felt in the form of a higher wheat area in the 1998 harvest at the earliest.
The 10 million acres of land probably freed up from CRP contracts would extend the joint U.S. area of grains, rice, oilseeds and cotton by just four percent, Toepfer said.
It based this figure on 260 million acres -- calculated from the average of the combined crops over the last three years.
"(The four percent) extension of production capacity would be more than necessary, given the anticipated rate of demand growth across the world," Toepfer wrote.
